docs.abstract: M Sheraton evaluates nouvelle cuisine as developed by French chefs and popularized in Europe and US; drawing; restaurants stress seasonal foods, cooked in fresh and light sauces (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: No culinary movement has ever earned so much fame so quickly as France's nouvelle cuisine. Although the new cooking was christened by the French food critics Henri Gault and Christian Mil lau 10 years ago, it had already been developing for at least 10 years before that. Now, as this gastronomic revolution ...

headline.main: The New Japanese Masters of French Cuisine

docs.abstract: In Paris, three young chefs from Japan, and one from France, have opened the city’s most original new restaurants.
docs.lead_paragraph: At his new eponymous restaurant on the Left Bank in Paris, the Japanese chef Shinsuke Nakatani entitles his menu “An Homage to France.” It speaks to the growing reverence for Gallic gastronomy among the new generation of Japanese chefs — three of whom have recently opened some of the French capital’s best and most original new restaurants.
docs.snippet: In Paris, three young chefs from Japan, and one from France, have opened the city’s most original new restaurants....

headline.main: Cuisine Art | The Dish on White Zinfandel

docs.abstract: The creators of White Zinfandel, a mash-up of art, food and culture, discuss its origins.
docs.lead_paragraph: "Of course it happened over a dinner conversation," says Jiminie Ha of the origins of White Zinfandel, the magazine she started with her friends, the architects Chris and Dominic Leong. The mash-up of art, food and culture celebrated the publication of its second issue, "TV Dinners," this past weekend with a dinner at Jack Hanley Gallery in TriBeCa. "Since art and food are our two biggest obsessions, we thought it would be interesting to marry the two in an unexpected way," explains Ha, who heads up the multidisciplinary studio W/-Projects. "It was an experiment that explores the high- and low-brow aspects of both creative fields."
docs.snippet: The creators of White Zinfandel, a mash-up of art, food and culture, discuss its origins....

headline.main: Canned Soup as Art - and Haute Cuisine

docs.abstract: Food | How modern cooking and modern art are alike: Just as Andy Warhol embraced popular culture rather than shun it in the name of "real art," so too do the chefs of "molecular gastronomy" like Ferran Adrià embrace the tools of modern food production - "the same tools that give us freeze-dried vegetables and Top Ramen." Rice Krispies paella, anyone? [Smart Set]

headline.main: Japanese Cuisine That's Suited for Fusion

docs.lead_paragraph: I CAN'T remember when I first heard the term ''fusion cuisine'' to describe a style that combines the cooking of several cultures in one dish. What I am certain of is that fusion developed a bad reputation not long afterward. It came to mean food that was neither one thing nor another, in which the marriage of cultures blurred their distinctiveness and created a mush rather than a genuinely new cuisine.

headline.main: Celebrating the Cuisine of New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: There are plenty of recipes in ''Farms and Foods of the Garden State: A New Jersey Cookbook'' by Brian Yarvin (Hippocrene Books, $18.95), but its real interest lies in its profiles of New Jersey's farmers and food producers. The book features people like Louis Condo, a former construction worker who grows blueberries at his Big Buck Farms in Hammonton, and Charlie Wong, who came from Taiwan to grow yams and melons at Chia-Sin Farms in Pittstown.

headline.main: Outings Near Paris For Classic Cuisine

docs.abstract: Choice Tables column reviews four classic French restaurants on outskirts of Paris: Les Magnolias, Relais Ste-Jeanne, Tastevin and L'Hostellerie du Nord; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the many overlooked pleasures of Paris is how easy it is to get out of. There are chateaus and parks and charming villages all within a 50-mile radius of the city. What's more, there is some pretty terrific dining. Over the past three months several friends and I have made a point of hopping on the various local train lines (called the R.E.R.) for day trips to nearby destinations, always with a good meal in mind. We were never disappointed.

docs.abstract: William Grimes reviews Verbena, Manhattan restaurant; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN the nearly seven years that it has been open, Verbena has carved out a niche that only seems to get nichier as time goes on. Early on, it stood out, if a restaurant this quiet and intimate can be said to stand out, as a lone outpost of elegant cuisine in a neighborhood of takeout shops and taverns. With the emergence of Park Avenue South as a restaurant strip geared to younger diners in search of cool bars and hot chefs, Verbena seems almost Garboesque in its languid disengagement from the sizzling scene swirling around it. Until recently, Verbena was a one-woman performance piece by Diane Forley, who, as chef and owner, served up an intriguing synthesis of American ingredients and Middle Eastern flavors. Things have changed. The restaurant closed for a face-lift and an expansion. And Ms. Forley married Michael Otsuka, another cultural synthesizer, who brought a distinctive, very modern kind of Asian-American cuisine to the theater district in his brief tenure as chef at Thalia. They now share cooking duties, and ideas, in Verbena's kitchen.
